segments.speaker: A

All right, I think you guys are going to like this one. I'm Pat Walls and this is Starter story. All right Mark, welcome to the channel. segments.speaker: A
segments.text: Yeah, so I'm 19, I'm from Kazakhstan. I built one of the biggest design agencies to start Silicon Valley, scale the team to 20 people and doing around $80,000 a month.

segments.speaker: B

We work with one of the biggest names in AI niche such as Bolt New Korea AI. We partner up with Kramer, with Wolf, with the Contra. So the idea behind our agency is we help you to get noticed. We usually don't focus on conversions or little tweaks in landing page. We help to make something that will go viral. Cool.

segments.speaker: B
segments.text: Before we get into, you know, how you grew, how you built this thing, I mean I look at your website right now, the design is amazing. How do you get into this design world and then build a pretty big company out of it?

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: More than five years ago, I opened the FEMA for the first time and I switched from front end. I was a developer to design at the time. I was just working with some local clients in Kazakhstan. I got a couple of small clients on local websites. I was slightly, slightly getting more experience and slightly growing. Right then in the January of 2024 I decided to open my X account for the first time and started posting consistently. A few months passed by, I got like 5 to 6k followers and in November of 2024 I opened my agency. So on average I think we juggle between six to seven clients a month. Some of them are one off products, some of them are retailers and I would say our average price for retailers is about 20k a month.

segments.speaker: B
segments.text: Okay, cool. Well, I mean, I think what's amazing about your business is that you don't have like a million clients. You just have a few really, really solid clients that pay you a lot of money per month. Can you break down how you got your first big client?

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: Yeah, sure. So for the whole summer, like 2024, I was applying for all the UX UI web design row I could find and eventually all of them rejected me. So I decided to make like a new like campaign where I would do the free redesigns for these big brands. And WOP was the first one that I did. I took the landing page, redesigned the hero section and made a post about that. And the post blew up to like 110k views, I think like overnight, even though WOP itself didn't notice me. But at this time I got around of 10 to 12 call bookings overnight and closed majority of them. So it basically was my first month of running an agency and making this new campaign and it turned out super good.

segments.speaker: B
segments.text: Okay, cool. I mean, I love this. So could you just show me actually right now a post that you did free work that led to clients.

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: Basically this day I had a flight from Kazakhstan to San Francisco because I was going to the Bold event. I also met with the boat team and I show it to them and they reached out to me maybe like in a week and we started working together. And here's another example of the free work we've done. We did a redesign for the homepage of acquisition.com and then Alex Hormozzi himself, he noticed this, right? And he actually responded to this tweet and this post. I would say it's probably the highest conversing post of my life. Maybe broke, maybe like 15, 16 call bookings every night.

segments.speaker: B
segments.text: Cool. I think the next thing that some people watch this are probably wondering is, okay, I don't have an audience. So if I do free work and I share it publicly, nobody's going to see it. I'd love if you shared your playbook for getting early audience, getting those first few thousand followers, if you're doing anything in design or really anything in marketing online.

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: So step one, to start using this free work strategy, you first of all need to have an X account. So you need to get some followers, spend a lot of time engaging with other people in your niche. I was just leaving like 50 comments a day on other designers post. Step two, you go from with amount of followers like a few hundred followers to a few thousand followers by doing giveaways. The three things you can give away is usually the knowledge, the product or the service. So thing is, you basically say like to get this, you need to follow me, you need to leave a comment, you need to repost, right? And then I will send it to you like in the DMs. And basically because of the giveaways, I was able to go maybe like from 500 followers to 5k followers in a couple of months by doing maybe like three giveaways in total. Step three, I would say would be to download the tweet Hunter extension. You needed to see the most viral content of people in your niche, so then you can replicate that. Step four will be to experiment as much with the content as you can. Because the thing is, 3 to 5k followers is actually the best range of followers you can have. Why? Because you are big enough to make some of your content blow up, right? And you're not big enough for people to care about you enough. So you can like make like a bunch of posts and just like test new ideas, test everything you have in mind. And let's say if it's not good enough, then people just will not notice that it doesn't matter. You will not hurt your reputation. And if it's good enough, then it will blow up. And step five would be to make something cool for these big ass brands. How it works is that you find the most viral brands people talk about right now. So right now it may be clearly. So every month, every couple of months, people have something new to talk about. And your idea is to spend as much time to make the highest quality of work for this trending brand name to then make it go viral.

I have a bunch of friends who make like 30-40k mrr without the website. So I would say if you just start out, everything's free.

segments.speaker: B
segments.text: Thanks for sharing all those tools. If you could go back in time and stand on Mark's shoulder before you had any clients, what would be your number one piece of advice or advice for anyone who's watching this that wants to get started and build something like you?

segments.speaker: A
segments.text: People usually underestimate the amount of work you actually need to put in. Right? So I always ask myself, what's the number of times you need to repeat this specific task that the chances of you not getting a client or a lead will be close to zero. How many times I need to like do the code DMs? How many times I need to post the content for? The chances of me not getting something from that will be close to zero.

segments.speaker: B
